title: World History: Ancient to Modern: Grades 9-12
subject: Social Studies (2023-)

document.title: South Dakota Social Studies Standards Adopted April 17, 2023

78B478EDC6CF4E0F95B6E5A8751F93CE.description:
The student describes the present-day economies, social and governmental structures,
cultures, and ways of life in the following regions, including the several key forms of
government within each region: Middle East, Norther Africa, Sub-Saharan Africa, Asia, Oceana,
North America, Central America, South America, Eastern Europe, Western Europe, the
Balkans, Australia. HCGE

64CE374A4B264375B1443BB0A65B8DBC.description: The student explains the causes of the 2008 financial crisis. HE

D8FA78199A4B419BA1113FF74ADBFD97.description:
The student explains the formation of the European Union, the growing role of Asian nations
in the global economy, and the power of nongovernmental organizations. HEÂ

124239FF52914358B249BB60263DE4A5.description:
The student explains the globalization of world economies, technology, and communications
during the late 20th Century and early 21st Century. HE

77632D85484D434C9C6D22F9C2690BF1.description: The student explains the end of apartheid in South Africa and the role of Nelson Mandela. H

807735D7CE09444589C10B856F662353.description:
The student identifies and explains the various conflicts since the end of the Cold War,
including in Northern Ireland, the Balkans, Sudan and Rwanda, Somalia, Sri Lanka, Kashmir,
Afghanistan, Iraq, Libya, and Syria. H

6D5D2B3FE71B40A5BC535FEC3D70D0FB.description:
The student explains the collapse of the Soviet Union and the end of the Cold War, including
the weakness of the command economy, policies of United States President Ronald Reagan,
local resistance, and the roles of Aleksander Solzhenitsyn, Michael Gorbachev, John Paul II,
Vaclav Havel, and Lech Walesa. H

3D682934E5E74FA782D04379CEDEABEE.description:
The student explains the cultural revolution and protests across much of Europe in the 1960s
and 1970s. H

B48B59D30BCC41888F90AF31F670862B.description:
The student explains the rise in economic productivity during the late 20th Century and its
effects on the standard of living across the world. E

ACBAC27188AC48A69F1360809BCF6968.description:
The student explains the major events in the decolonization of Asia, Africa, Latin America, and
the Middle East. H

4F9F8902E7B54BF3850E9775FAAD12E4.description:
The student explains the various uprisings and proxy wars that were part of the Cold War,
including the Greek Civil War, the Korean War, the Hungarian uprising, the Cuban Revolution,
the Vietnam War, Cambodian genocide, the Prague Spring, and the Afghan-Soviet War. H

BFEAB886D9D04233B7451506B219E8FC.description:
The student explains the main communist principles within Communist China, the role of Mao
Zedong, the use of terror, and the violations of the rights and the murder of millions of people
under communist rule, including the Great Leap Forward, the Cultural Revolution, and
Tiananmen Square. H

D4CE58ADA7184870BEDE052F8F2CD9D5.description:
The student explains the ideas and tactics used by the Soviet Union and the United States in
the early decades of the Cold War, including the growth of intelligence agencies. H

9A11060150F641A6B1BA616C2620DD4A.description: The student explains the major events of the Chinese Civil War. H

07E47B06D60F4BA6856ABABF3BD3033D.description: The student demonstrates knowledge and understanding of the world since World War II.Â

BE9783075801423CA42A3B076DA62C08.description:
The student explains the founding of the modern state of Israel and subsequent events in the
Middle East. H

7BFC8778785049CA8888FD9D60A04F52.description: The student explains the ends and means of the Marshall Plan and the United Nations. H

C4C795AA89104344933931E012D7C7B6.description:
The student explains the physical, moral, psychological, and political effects of World War II
and the emergence of the United States and the Soviet Union as superpowers. H

33C46BDB55804B8A91BAF96F0DAE93E3.description:
The student explains the figures, warfare, strategies, and major events of World War II,
including the invasions of Poland and France, Battle of Britain, Operation Barbarossa, Pearl
Harbor, Stalingrad, Guadalcanal, fighting in North Africa and Italy, D-Day, Okinawa, the atomic
bombings, and the role of America. H

C29607343AA1478DB981C1A9DDC8D8A2.description:
The student explains the general causes of World War II as well as the particular series of
events that led to the outbreak of war in 1939, including the perceived injustice of the
Versailles Treaty and its subsequent violations by Germany, the annexations of Austria and
Czechoslovakia, the Nazi-Soviet Nonaggression Pact, and the invasions of Poland. H

B92EEDE1648842E085081B50E00DCA31.description:
The student explains the impact of National Socialism within Germany and the role of Adolf
Hitler in using German democratic processes to take power, to consolidate political power
within Germany, to expand Germanyâs borders, to conduct an industrial age war, and to carry
out the Holocaust. H

093623EF3F04498AAFB4294C1A4D6967.description:
The student explains the main fascist principles within Fascist Italy and Imperial Japan, the
roles of Benito Mussolini and Hideki Tojo, the use of terror, and the violations of the rights of
and the murder of millions of people under fascist rule, including the invasion of Ethiopia, the
Nanjing Massacre, and the impact on Italian occupied Africa and Japanese occupied China and
south-east Asian nations. H

8E5745E872B64A6BA9F0EB1BA1DC7544.description:
The student explains the main communist principles within the Soviet Union, the roles of
Vladimir Lenin, Leon Trotsky, and Josef Stalin, the use of terror, and the violations of the rights
and the murder of millions of people under communist rule, including the Holodomor, the
invasion of Poland, and the gulag archipelago. H

92243F6935C04011BE5692151B443EBB.description:
The student explains the major causes of the Great Depression and the responses of various
economic thinkers and governments, including John Maynard Keynes, Ludwig von Mises,
Friedrich von Hayek, and Milton Friedman. H

98781A1065964D2583141D5C59487487.description:
The student explains the growing international role of the Middle East during the 20th Century,
including the fall of the Ottoman Empire and rise of a secular Turkish state, the Balfour
Declaration, the Palestine Mandate, and the importance of oil fields. H

F71CADC7F5DD4243AF3CF4E4B7A09DB4.description:
The student explains the physical, moral, psychological, and political effects of World War I on
European society. H

3082ACC0FFBB4A2EA8DD303B7F93D1CE.description:
The student explains the causes and events of both the February Revolution and the Bolshevik
Revolution in Russia, including widespread violence and the assassinations of the Romanovs. H

B10B672D7F5244A887D1E31D451C6CD4.description:
The student explains the terms of the Treaty of Versailles, including the extent to which they
accurately reflected the outcome of the war and a just peace for the belligerent parties. H

286818D8937A4170991F0C213A7E666D.description:
The student explains the figures, warfare, strategies, and major events of World War I,
including the battles of the Marne, Gallipoli the Somme, and Verdun, the Armenian genocide,
the sinking of the Lusitania, unrestricted submarine warfare, and the role of America. H

42D3584EC8C0437BAA5C93A21D0C3F45.description:
The student explains the general causes of World War I as well as the particular series of
events that led to the outbreak of war in 1914, including imperial competition, nationalism,
militarism, an emerging power vacuum, and human hubris and fallibility. H

05EE58759BC24053A36046834DD764B2.description:
The student demonstrates knowledge and understanding of the world wars and the
interwar years.

AC6F7ADAE90141148A3CA847F8C06419.description:
The student explains the presence and influence of Hegelianism, nationalism, and militarism
among the leaders and citizenry of various European powers by the dawn of the 20th century.
HÂ

6476475B06474E3FB0FB139A0A425D0F.description:
The student explains the unifications of Italy and Germany, the domestic situation in Russia,
and shifts in the balance of power during the late 19th Century. HÂ

41BB95450F944F81A1D66A4998DBB821.description:
The student explains the major developments in Latin American history in the early 19th and
early 20th centuries, including the wars of independence, the growing influence of the United
States, and the Mexican Revolution. H

ABE1AF84DB5E45FB8FA9795ABA2F0CDA.description:
The student explains the colonization of Africa and Asia during the 19th Century and its
effects, including developing economies and technology, the spread of Christianity, atrocities,
Indian nationalism, the decline of the Manchu dynasty, Chinese nationalism, and the Meiji
Restoration. H

78B336730BDC458CBC4E77A219F3D398.description:
The student explains the abolitionist movements in the United States and Great Britain during
the 19th Century. H

EBF717E3800148D799826C8824A7E0C2.description:
The student explains the ideas of Georg Hegel, Karl Marx, and Social Darwinism, including the
progress of history, dialectical materialism, communist revolution, the role of violence, and
the dictatorship of the proletariat. HCE

C9C045A601FD445B8E69FC212CEC876B.description:
The student describes the different responses to the challenges of industrialization and the
growth of large corporations, including various reform efforts and socialism. HE

04D4FFF02D534F6FA1EE06C565FD558D.description:
The student describes the Second Industrial Revolution and the emerging challenges that local
communities, small businesses, and workers faced. HÂ

C4A04180D02B47FB963A94171B8EC7BB.description:
The student explains major historical events involving Victorian England and the British
Empire, including reform efforts in Great Britain and policies within colonies. HÂ

6F308DF5E29B4B1D9589873B9679F52C.description:
The student explains the effects of the French Revolution and Napoleonic Empire, including
romanticism, nationalism, liberalism, and the pattern of revolutions that emerged in the first
half of the 19th century in Europe and in Central and South America. H

C0C3FD64D4FA4A5F91B101EF45A21788.description:
The student explains the events that led to the rise of Napoleon Bonaparte, his conquests in in
Europe, and the outcome of the Congress of Vienna. H

E23A86013AF6417589DE1AF5693392B7.description:
The student explains the origins and major historical events of the French Revolution,
including the ideas of Voltaire and Jean-Jacque Rousseau, government corruption, the effects
of the American Revolution on France, the role of the mob and a lack of experience in selfgovernment, and widespread violence. H

67A0C7BDB81C4A3CABC7DCC1385C5B41.description:
The student demonstrates knowledge and understanding of the French Revolution and
the 19th Century.Â

5FE1BA3570AE458A9A0D781C9F011DEF.description:
The student explains how a free market or capitalist market indicates that laws allow
individuals to possess more goods or currency than they need to survive; and to invest,
produce, distribute, and buy and sell goods and services by making their own agreements with
one another. H

00546FE800274D7992A109310E1EAA0E.description:
The student explains the origins and effects of the Agricultural Revolution, the First Industrial
Revolution, and the Enclosure Movement in England, including Adam Smithâs observations on
the capitalist nature of an industrial society. H

EF2B46F74A414589B78CE8CB6A5EF232.description:
The student explains the origins, political ideas, historical events, and effects of the English
Civil War, the Protectorate, and the Glorious Revolution, and how England was the exception
to absolutism. H

760BD1990D6148079010142B50E49FDB.description:
The student describes the monarchy of Louis XIV and its effect on other monarchs in Europe in
the form of enlightened absolutism, including in Russia, Austria, and Prussia. H

DF96F15BFE5D414DB6F3CB1FA8281509.description:
The student explains the major ideas of the Enlightenment, including the ideas of NiccolÃ³
Machiavelli, Rene Descartes, Thomas Hobbes, John Locke, Voltaire, and Jean-Jacques
Rousseau, and their expression in neo-classical art. H

E6C9A0D83D16443BB30F33295CB7AAE9.description:
The student explains the scientific method and the major ideas and discoveries of the
Scientific Revolution. H

55CF0782FE7846B28C899CEB8959A196.description: The student describes life on a slave ship in the Middle Passage. H

12F2E7504C1948AA8DBDD167A63F4813.description:
The student explains the approaches of different powers to exploration and colonization in
the Western Hemisphere, especially how Englandâs approach was distinct. H

75FFB6EB638F44579ED399EE604FBBC3.description:
The student explains the Columbian Exchange of resources, people, and disease, including
how smallpox decimated indigenous peoples and the science of why this happened. H

480A038EDE4F4E51832C94418C2E0BA7.description:
The student explains instances of conquest and cooperation between Europeans and
indigenous peoples in the Americas until 1800. H

0991B5CA8E1940249DD568CA72771F81.description:
The student explains the political and religious elements to the wars of religion in the 16th and
17th centuries, including the Anglo-Spanish War, the French Wars of Religion, and the Thirty
Yearsâ War. H

C18A0AD98350410A95C94ECA9690B340.description:
The student identifies the figures and features of Elizabethan England and the English
Renaissance. H

FFD2D056D016419283FECCA0A4B47FFC.description:
The student demonstrates knowledge and understanding of the Age of Exploration, the Scientific
Revolution, the Enlightenment, and the Industrial Revolution.Â

88D9BA412B8A4BC48B6EAA2C40BE82E6.description:
The student explains the major historical events during the Protestant Reformation and the
subsequent Catholic Reformation, including their reflection in art, architecture, and politics. H

2CAB8BF57EB64A908D9BF8A5D251D4CA.description:
The student explains the main ideas of major Protestant leaders, including Martin Luther,
Henry VIII and Thomas Cranmer, and John Calvin, and how they contrasted with Catholic ideas
and practices. H

A083216268C34D178F8AA410C5FCAA44.description:
The student explains the 15th century slave trade among Africans, Arabs, and Europeans, and
compares it to the practice of indentured servitude. H

EF224970FED047A69C871CAA722ECFA5.description:
The student explains 15th century trade between Europe and Asia, and different European
motivations for exploration. H

1AA1759D5A6548378C4969C9CA97F932.description:
The student explains the Reconquista of the Iberian Peninsula with the decline of Muslim rule
and the ascendance of the Portuguese and Spanish crowns. H

3BFBEF294FC746079A71C0CD845AD38C.description:
The student explains the major cultural features and contributions of the Renaissance in Italy
and Northern Europe in painting, architecture, sculpture, and literature. H

2F1749FE702A4A21BE80665EEF7481FA.description:
The student explains the origins and major ideas of the Renaissance, including humanism, the
growth of towns, the model of Dante Alighieri, and the roles of patrons. H

F5C3A75F1D5F4222B14C94EFEE3316CC.description:
The student explains the disruptions to society in the late Middle Ages and their effects,
including the emergence of several strong monarchies, the Avignon Papacy, the Black Death,
the Great Schism of 1378, the Hundred Yearsâ War, the Ottoman Empireâs capture of
Constantinople, the ideas of John Wycliffe, Jan Hus, and Donatism, and Ivan IIIâs end of
Mongol rule. H

7076FB44CDC9474E8AD06004A9DFD62E.description:
The student explains the history and features of civilization and culture in certain indigenous
tribes in North and South America prior to European exploration, including the Ancestral
Pueblo, Hopewell, Aztec, Maya, Inca, and various independent tribes. H

548F720DFBBA42AFA3A59E29FFBCC4BD.description:
The student explains the history and features of civilizations in Japan, including Shinto and
Japanese Buddhism, feudalism, shoguns, isolationism, and its cultural rivalry with the Chinese
on the Korean Peninsula. H

25F4D75B7D064640934FB3AA13E20FE0.description:
The student explains the history and features of civilizations in China, including Confucianism,
commerce, agriculture, and the major dynasties. H

DD0CD35B66174A948D0081F76BC883FA.description:
The student explains the history and features of civilizations in India, including Hinduism, the
caste system, and Mongol and Muslim rule. H

FD0CA52698974DD6AD6D637DFD3D9623.description:
The student explains the history and features of civilizations in Africa, including indigenous
religious practices, the role of kinship relationships, the influence of Islam and Christianity, the
civilizations of Ghana, Mali, and Songhay, their economic and political practices, and the transAfrican slave trade. HÂ

581B309A82D441208317F3D9C90D990C.description:
The student demonstrates knowledge and understanding of the Late Middle Ages, the
Renaissance, and the Reformation.Â

0C7EFEF1B4C2493284912942960A8859.description:
The student explains the developments and achievements of the high Middle Ages, including
the power of the papacy, the founding of mendicant orders, the rise of universities, and the
major ideas of scholasticism and Thomas of Aquino, Maimonides, and Ibn Sina. H

030F845B415D48129A9FAE312351770B.description:
The student explains the origins, historical events, and different perspectives of the conflicts
between Muslims and Christians both before and during the crusades, including the exchange
of ideas and culture between Christians and Muslims that took place during these centuries. H

96BDE9B70DF34980A255CE87F916150E.description:
The student tells of the Norman Conquest, the rule of King John of England, the signing of the
Magna Carta, and the emergence of parliament. H

9B3FE23EE0CB4012B26B1821E7108101.description:
The student explains the origin of the Great Schism of 1054, the Investiture Controversy, and
the Concordat of Worms. H

73036982EB114264BF0278530DA6D280.description:
The student describes and explains Christian and Muslim art and architecture in the Middle
Ages. H

9C5E36CE784D45729762D7AD18604398.description:
The student explains the development and practice of feudalism in European societies,
including the expectations of each class, and of slavery in the Middle East, Africa, and Asia. H

FA578374417048489F41C200A56C8F37.description:
The student explains the historical events and effects of the Carolingian dynasty, the
establishment of the Holy Roman Empire, the Viking invasions, and the rule of Vladimir of
Kiev. H

984F2C0F3A4A421194EA869EE22ADC3F.description:
The student explains the major historical events, cultural features, stories, and religious
contributions of early Muslims, including the origins and role of the Qurâan, the preservation
of Greek thought, and expansions in science, philosophy, and mathematics. H

DB5F533FB6D14CB29BE0CAFEFE8507E8.description:
The student explains the major ideas and events surrounding the life of Mohammed and their
historical effects, including the founding and spread of Islam and divisions between Sunnis and
Shiâites. H

4A1245983173431FB4552C6F07930ECE.description:
The student explains the establishment of monasteries, the practices of monasticism, the
preservation of ancient thought, and their role in the Middle Ages. HÂ

C63AF22BE56C44FEB2DF8F43C0269179.description:
The student explains the ways in which society changed with the fall of the Roman Empire and
the perpetuation of the Eastern Roman Empire in Constantinople, including the role of
Christianity. H

3657EBA4B8B54B3B90DEB3B1BDACB989.description:
The student explains the origins and cultures of the major indigenous tribes of Europe around
500, including the Ostrogoths, Burgundians, Franks, Visigoths, Lombards, Saxons, Angles,
Britons, Celts, Slavs, and Norse. H

4282247A85F24723A91AD24F859EA012.description: The student demonstrates knowledge and understanding of the Middle Ages.Â Â

484BAF48248E4A14BC37F165F0A2FA13.description:
The student explains the role of the papacy and historical figures in establishing Christianity
and Roman law in Europe and the near east, including the Christian church fathers, Augustine
of Hippo, Leo I, and Justinian. H

EA8D17FDDD554D5FBA2FFF0E7DCD715A.description:
The student explains the origins of the barbarian invasions and the other factors that led to
the fall of the Roman Empire, including the power of the military establishment, political
corruption, and economic instability arising from opulence. H

89B99BD3BA78436CB9E4B12284650694.description:
The student compares the religion of the Christians to that of the Hebrews and of polytheist
religions, including monotheism, the Trinity, the belief in Jesus of Nazareth as divine, the
redeeming of a personâs sins, the individual worth of each person, and equal moral obligations
of each person regardless of class or authority. H

AEDD5DEFD8994E4988A2D3E9B157DB25.description:
The student explains the major historical events, cultural features, stories, and religious
contributions of the early Christians, including the origins and role of the Bible. H

19946BE40F544ED5AE8C40EC8DFFD5C3.description:
The student explains the major events during the rule of Constantine, including the
legalization of Christianity and the moving of the Roman capital to Constantinople. H

E7709ADB21DE4F2D84EB402C9ED3EEC4.description:
The student explains the major historical events and cultural features of the Roman Empire,
including under the rule of Octavian Caesar, the Julio-Claudian dynasty, Trajan, Hadrian,
Marcus Aurelius, and Diocletian. H

9BAE5E51EA71459982121269C618B7D1.description:
The student explains the factors that accounted for the Roman Empireâs relative stability and
longevity, including its military organization and tactics, the Pax Romana, decentralized
administration, the taxation system, a standard currency, and the road system. H

23B8D18CB6D14795ACFA9D2FDF9760F8.description:
The student explains the major ideas and events surrounding the life of Jesus of Nazareth and
their historical effects, including the establishment of early Christian churches, the spread of
Christianity, and persecutions of Christians. H

61233447E0FC4E729B256A8CB9A41601.description:
The student explains the origins and major events of the Roman civil wars and the
triumvirates, including the ideas and actions of Cato the Elder, Cicero, Julius Caesar, and
Octavian Caesar. H

4E3ADC91E7DB45B7BC786717A659A479.description:
The student explains the causes, warfare, strategy, outcomes, and effects of the Punic Wars,
including the battles of Cannae and Zama and the roles of Hamilcar Barca, Hannibal, and
Scipio Africanus. H

261FE373257D4100B5D06A79474EB60E.description:
The student explains the major cultural features and contributions of Rome, including in
architecture, engineering, sculpture, poetry, slavery, the Latin language, and the histories of
Livy, Tacitus, and Polybius. H

320F78532C8F4C01AA72F4FCDB62E461.description:
The student explains the social and political organization of the Roman Republic and the
influence of its governing principles and institutions, including the rule of law, the separation
of powers, ideas of civic duty, and representative government. HC

32EBCB4442DA44B39EEFCC052E9B2C28.description:
The student explains the stories and events surrounding the founding of Rome and the Roman
Republic. H

5DF4C8A6A353496E81F0C0106C82B177.description:
The student demonstrates knowledge and understanding of the Roman Republic and
the Roman Empire.Â Â

1030AA2A5CF24CB3BFCEAB335B080BDF.description:
The student tells of the conquests of Alexander of Macedon, the founding of the city of
Alexandria, and the spread of Greek culture in the Hellenistic Period. H

E3E24552B81B42CC98F0B3080CCABF79.description:
The student explains the major ideas of philosophers and religious thinkers in antiquity,
including Siddhartha, Confucius, Thales, Pythagoras, Hippocrates, Socrates, Plato, Aristotle,
and Epicurus, especially in terms of logical reasoning, truth, and ethics. HC

3C955CE50F864A10AA11E1ACBB8F29C6.description:
The student explains the causes, warfare, strategy, outcomes, and effects of the
Peloponnesian War, including the roles of Pericles and Demosthenes. H

826099F8F3804FBD9830F41DCD3CABF9.description:
The student explains the major cultural features and contributions of Athens during the
classical period, including pottery, architecture, sculpture, drama, the Greek language,
institutions, slavery, and the histories of Herodotus and Thucydides. H

AC41C43F2BF543368F5A65389CD4CDFA.description:
The student explains the causes, warfare, strategy, outcomes, and effects of the Persian Wars,
including the battles of Marathon, Thermopylae, and Salamis. H

5BAD509E996B435CA4A6FAFA4D267B20.description:
The student explains why the government of ancient Athens may be considered the beginning
of democracy, including the polis, written constitutions, voting, a legislative body, and the rule
of law. HC

1F3CA5611CBF49D7BB955F3EEFCE9DB4.description: The student identifies the major figures and stories within Greek and Roman mythology. H

0D1269A1EC7145159119173C3E1669E1.description:
The student explains the major historical events, cultural features, and contributions of
civilizations in Peloponnesus and the eastern Mediterranean Sea, including Minoa, Mycenae,
and archaic Sparta and Athens. H

19406E8D1ED241838073269BB3158FDE.description:
The student compares the monotheistic religion of the Hebrews to the traditional polytheism
of the ancient world, including the belief in one god, the Decalogue, individual worth of each
person, and equal moral obligations of each person regardless of class or authority. H

A731BC28F9234AA6A044E4E01622605F.description:
The student explains the major historical events, cultural features, and stories of the ancient
Hebrews, including the origins and role of the Tanakh. H

BDF9BE457B554F91B3DF8BD6278ACEB9.description:
The student explains the major historical events, cultural features, stories, and civil
contributions of Ancient Egypt and Phoenicia, including agriculture, the calendar, hieroglyphic
writing, papyrus, maritime commerce, and the first alphabet. HC

FDDFC5F005AA4F8FB979B3339754A9EF.description:
The student explains the major historical events, cultural features, stories, and civil
contributions of Ancient India, Sumer, Babylon, Assyria, Persia, and Ancient China, including
polytheism, irrigation, metalsmithing, the domestication of animals, slavery, and inventions
such as the wheel, sail, plow, and writing. HC

B390B39BCDEE48CE9EBBCB8E8FF09E0B.description:
The student explains the origins of human beings in Africa and traces the development of
early human civilization through the Neolithic Age, including the roles of climate and
environmental changes, hunter-gatherer societies, metallurgy, and agriculture. H

1AB009666E3A42D69B1BEA190E9B6C52.description:
The student identifies the six characteristics of civilizations: large population centers,
monumental architecture and unique art styles, shared communication strategies, systems for
administering territories, a complex division of labor, and the division of people into social and
economic classes. HCE

E791B1C538194CD5B65D94896EA84C1D.description:
The student demonstrates knowledge and understanding of ancient civilizations in Asia, the
Middle East, northern Africa, and the eastern Mediterranean Sea.

FDB9AC46E222408AA27FA1B38F5BF054.description:
The student can write a persuasive essay of 500-750 words based on class notes, including a
main argument (thesis), topic sentences, supporting evidence from history and class, and clear
attempts to explain how the evidence proves the topic sentences and overall thesis. HCE

090E7865119D4665B5D1C4DF89EEF1F2.description:
The student can write an informative essay of 500-750 words on a historical figure based on
class notes. HÂ

1CC69B3C8E004C858C21B7BA3167F033.description:
The student can write a narrative essay of 500-750 words on a historical event based on class
notes. H

C08C148E1074440799B05CC185971229.description:
Building upon skills learned in previous grades, the student learns the skills to complete the
following tasks, completing each task with relative ease by the end of high school.Â Â
